text:
3 THINGS THAT MATTER ABOUT THE $NVDA + GROQ DEAL

1. This was about owning inference economics, not fixing a chip gap 

Nvidia didn't aqui-hired Groq because it was behind on chips since Nvidia already dominates training and most inference & its roadmap (GB300, Rubin) continues to push cost-per-token down while expanding performance faster than nearly anyone else. Training is a one-time event while inference is where the new AI business model lives so as AI moves into real products the money shifts to whoever controls runtime.

2. The future where inference escapes Nvidia just got absorbed

Groq was one of the few credible proofs that latency-sensitive inference could eventually move off GPUs and over time that would have chipped away at Nvidia‚Äôs ‚Äúunavoidable‚Äù status. The risk was amplified by Groq‚Äôs founder Jonathan Ross, who previously built TPUs at $GOOGL and already proved that custom silicon can compete in real workloads. This deal shuts that door before it could scale. 

3. Deterministic inference was the missing layer

GPUs excel at flexibility and scale but they were never designed to guarantee perfectly consistent response times. That matters because real-world AI breaks when latency jitters: voice assistants pause, live translation lags, agentic workflows compound delays. Groq solved this by designing around large amounts of SRAM by keeping data close to the processor and delivering quick responses every time. That made Groq uniquely suited for real-time AI where latency matters more than peak throughput.

At this point, it‚Äôs hard to argue Nvidia just sells chips when it‚Äôs clearly building the platform that owns training, networking, and now real-time inference.

$20B today to avoid a $200B problem later.

$NVDA AI business now generates ~$458M per day.

That figure was ~$40M per day just three years ago.

This is the power of owning the compute every AI system has to run on.

The Problem with Static P/E Charts

Media often cite elevated P/E ratios vs historical averages as proof of overvaluation.

But this assumes P/Es should be constant, ignoring shifts in growth, sentiment, capital costs, and demographics.

Learn more and view fund holdings at AOTETF.com. 

#Valuation #Markets #BehavioralFinance

The Price-to-Earnings (P/E) ratio measures what investors are willing to pay for each $1 of a company‚Äôs earnings.

For example, a P/E of 20 means investors are paying $20 for every $1 of earnings. Higher P/Es can reflect growth expectations, but they‚Äôre not always a sign of overvaluation.

Was with a friend the other night over hookah.

I told him I feel horribly alone.

It‚Äôs not about how many followers I have or how recognizable I‚Äôve become in the industry.

I feel horribly alone, and I know that I must feel this way to accomplish my goals.

I must do it alone.
Raw moment - I‚Äôm finding it hard to get into Christmas this year.

"If opportunity doesn't knock, build a door." - Milton Berle

This quote haunts me.

I think about this every day.

leadlagreport.com/p/value-vs‚Ä¶ Great article from @leadlagreport . Rotation, value, and a perspective of holding undervalued assets for the long-term over FOMO is the better path for now, even if it means a mean-reversion in risk assets (at least in my view) is pretty highly  likely in the next couple of years. If I had time to finish the FOMO series, which I do not, I would explain this concept in much greater detail, but I cannot at this time. This article expresses how to mitigate risk AND get alpha in the short and potentially longer-term timeframe. When I see what I want in terms of value in any asset class, I will return to paper assets in other than a trading mode. Everyone should educate themselves about the real nature of risk in the current market environment.

Value vs. Growth: Signs of a Long-Awaited Turn

open.substack.com/pub/leadla‚Ä¶
